## 1. Partners

We have identified three operational partners:

-   **GEOBON-International contributors**. This group includes not only contributors from the GEO BON international community but other international experts (currently not affiliated to GEO BON) that can provide valuable insigths on multiple topics of this initiative. **Using multiple cases studies**, this group will present which models and tools are available within and outside the GEO BON international community aimed to inform decision making and policy to protect, manage and monitor biodiversity, ecosystem services (i.e., carbon storage) and traditional food security (e.g., freshwater fisheries, foraging wild fruits). Case studies will illustrate what methods, models and tools have successfully worked. Moreover, What methods, models and tools have not worked? and Why?

-   **Regional experts.** This group will provide an evaluation of whether:

    -   these models and tools feasible to apply in this region.

    -   data sets currently available are enough for applying proposed models and tools.

-   **Implementers/users**: PC, ECCC, Indigenous partners, Provincial (MB, ON, QC). This group will promote a discussion with all partners to answer these questions, among others:

    -   How can local, regional and national partners can implement the proposed models and tools?

    -   What are pros, cons, trade-offs and assumptions to integrate them into decision making?

    -   What can be done now (tactical) and in the future?

    -   How can we inform decision-making based on the best available data?

    ![](Figures/Partners.png)

## 2. Pre-workshop activities

We expect GEO BON international contributors to **compile case studies** to show which methods, models and tools are available to inform decision making and policy to protect, manage and monitor biodiversity, ecosystem services (i.e., carbon storage) and traditional food security (e.g., freshwater fisheries, foraging wild fruits).

In general, we are looking to describe case studies with this minimum content:

-   Short description, including local/region context, communities involved, conservation issues, communities expectations, etc

-   Actions taken (management, policy-making, monitoring, community-based engagement, etc)

-   Results, impacts and lessons learned (positive, negative and unexpected)

-   References (papers, websites, grey literature, etc).

GEO BON has a supporting team (see below) that is currently compiling some case studies and we will be happy to support international contributors in in organizing their findings on this website. We will publish them as they become available.

## 3. Workshop

We will held a workshop with all partners.

-   **Date**: October 16 and 17, 2023 (Monday and Tuesday)

-   **Place and venue**: Montreal (venue TBD)

We expect a **stocktaking exercise, case study analysis**, and the outcome of the workshop with recommendations on appropriate tools and models, including the weaving of Traditional Knowledge into these that could be applied in the Hudson Bay-James Bay Lowlands.

We expect to have **breakout groups** and **plenary sessions**.

This **workshop summary report** will be the base of the final white paper.

## 6. Post-workshop

Develop and deliver a **discussion paper** based on stocktaking exercise, case study analysis, and the outcome of the workshop with recommendations on appropriate tools and models, including the weaving of Traditional Knowledge into these that could be applied in the Hudson Bay-James Bay Lowlands.

We will use the workshop summary report as a basis for the white paper.

Partners expect to review and **provide feedback/comments/suggestions/recommendations to first draft** of the white paper (most likely 2-3 months after the workshop).
